changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: A description (called alt-text) has been added to all images on the website. This text explains what is shown in the image.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Captions help people who are deaf or hard of hearing follow what’s being said in a video. They are also helpful when watching videos in noisy places or without sound.

wcag-a-1-2-1.title: 1.2.1 Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded) (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Transcripts or captions are provided for prerecorded audio content, and descriptive text or an alternative version is available for video-only content.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People who are deaf, hard of hearing, blind, or visually impaired need text alternatives to understand audio content, and audio descriptions to understand video-only content.

targeting.heading: Targeting
targeting.target1: Users who are deaf or hard of hearing (transcripts/captions for audio)
targeting.target2: Users who are blind or visually impaired (descriptive text for video-only)
targeting.target3: General users who may prefer text-based content over audio/video

wcag-a-1-2-1.implementation: Provide a text transcript for all audio content and an alternative description for video-only content.
wcag-a-1-2-1.technique: Use HTML `<track>` elements for captions, provide downloadable transcripts, or create alternative text descriptions in the content.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Text Captions have been added to the video. These show the spoken words as text on the screen.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Captions help people who are deaf or hard of hearing follow what’s being said in a video. They are also helpful when watching videos in noisy places or without sound.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: A media alternative has been added to the video. In this case, the alternative is a text version of whats spoken in the video.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People who are blind or have low vision can’t see what’s happening in videos. Alternatives explain important actions and details so they don’t miss any key information.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Headings, lists, and tables are now correctly marked so that their structure is clear—not just visually, but also in the code.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People using screen readers rely on the correct structure to understand how content is organized. It helps them navigate the page easily, just like sighted users who can see headings and sections.

wcag-a-1-3-2.title: 1.3.2 Meaningful Sequence (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The reading and navigation order of the content is structured logically, ensuring it makes sense when read sequentially, such as by a screen reader.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People who rely on assistive technologies, such as screen readers, need content to be presented in a meaningful order to understand relationships and navigate effectively.

targeting.heading: Targeting
targeting.target2: Users navigating with keyboard-only or voice commands
targeting.target3: People with cognitive disabilities who benefit from structured content

wcag-a-1-3-2.implementation: Ensure proper HTML structure using semantic elements like headings, lists, and landmark roles.
wcag-a-1-3-2.technique: Use correct HTML markup (e.g., `<h1>` to `<h6>`, `<nav>`, `<section>`) and logical DOM order.

wcag-a-1-3-3.title: 1.3.3 Sensory Characteristics (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Instructions or interactions do not rely solely on sensory characteristics like color, shape, size, or sound.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People who are blind, colorblind, or have other visual or auditory impairments may not be able to perceive instructions based solely on sensory cues.

targeting.heading: Targeting
targeting.target1: Users with visual impairments (blindness, color blindness, low vision)
targeting.target2: Users with auditory impairments (deaf or hard of hearing)
targeting.target3: Users with cognitive disabilities who may struggle with non-text instructions

wcag-a-1-3-3.implementation: Provide text-based alternatives or additional identifiers beyond sensory characteristics (e.g., 'Click the red button' should also say 'Click the red button labeled Submit').
wcag-a-1-3-3.technique: Use labels, icons with text, or ARIA attributes to supplement visual or auditory cues.

wcag-a-1-4-1.title: 1.4.1 Use of Color (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Color is not the only way information is conveyed. Other visual or text-based indicators are used to supplement color-based communication.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with color blindness or low vision may not be able to distinguish color-based information, making it inaccessible.

targeting.heading: Targeting
targeting.target2: Users with low vision who rely on high contrast
targeting.target3: Users who print materials in grayscale and lose color-based distinctions

wcag-a-1-4-1.implementation: Ensure that color-coded information (e.g., error messages, required fields, charts) is supplemented by text, icons, patterns, or other indicators.
wcag-a-1-4-1.technique: Use underlines for links instead of color alone, add labels to required form fields, and include patterns in graphs for differentiation.

wcag-a-1-4-2.title: 1.4.2 Audio Control (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: If a website includes audio that plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, users must be provided with a way to pause, stop, or control the volume.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users who rely on screen readers or who are sensitive to background noise need control over automatic audio to focus on the main content.

targeting.heading: Targeting
targeting.target1: Screen reader users (who need to hear their assistive technology without interference)
targeting.target2: Users with attention disorders or cognitive disabilities (who may be distracted by unexpected audio)
targeting.target3: Users in shared or quiet environments (who may need to silence unwanted sounds)

wcag-a-1-4-2.implementation: Provide user controls to pause, stop, or adjust the volume of automatically playing audio.
wcag-a-1-4-2.technique: Use `<audio>` elements with built-in controls, provide a visible mute button, or prevent autoplay entirely.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: All features on the website can now be accessed using only a keyboard (without a mouse).

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Some people can’t use a mouse due to mobility impairments. Keyboard navigation ensures they can still fully use the website.

wcag-a-2-1-2.title: 2.1.2 No Keyboard Trap (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users navigating via keyboard must be able to move focus into and out of interactive elements without getting trapped.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Keyboard-only users, such as individuals with motor impairments or screen reader users, need to navigate websites without getting stuck in an interface element that does not allow them to move forward or back.

targeting.heading: Targeting
targeting.target1: Users who rely on a keyboard or switch devices for navigation
targeting.target2: Screen reader users who tab through content sequentially
targeting.target3: Users with mobility impairments who cannot use a mouse

wcag-a-2-1-2.implementation: Ensure all interactive elements can be focused using the keyboard and allow users to exit using standard navigation methods (Tab, Shift+Tab, Escape).
wcag-a-2-1-2.technique: Use proper focus management, avoid JavaScript event handlers that trap focus, and provide an accessible method to close modal dialogs.

wcag-a-2-1-4.title: 2.1.4 Character Key Shortcuts (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: If a website has single-character keyboard shortcuts, users must be able to turn them off, remap them, or require a modifier key (such as Ctrl or Alt) to prevent accidental activation.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Keyboard-only users, speech input users, and individuals with motor impairments may accidentally trigger unwanted actions if single-key shortcuts are activated without control options.

targeting.heading: Targeting
targeting.target1: Users with motor impairments who might accidentally press keys
targeting.target2: Speech recognition users whose input could trigger unintended actions
targeting.target3: Screen reader users who frequently use keyboard navigation and shortcuts

wcag-a-2-1-4.implementation: Provide an option to disable, modify, or require additional keys (e.g., Ctrl, Alt) for single-character shortcuts.
wcag-a-2-1-4.technique: Ensure that keyboard shortcuts are configurable in user settings and avoid single-key triggers unless necessary.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Timers on the website can now be paused by clicking the button.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People with disabilities may need more time to read, respond, or complete tasks. Adjustable timers ensure they can complete a task in their time.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: A button has been added to pause any animation on the site.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Constant movement can be distracting or cause discomfort for some people, for example with attention disorders or vestibular issues. Providing a button is one possible way to achieve this criterion.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Content that flashes more than three times per second has been removed or adjusted to be below the flashing limit.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Flashing content can trigger seizures in people with photosensitive epilepsy. This rule helps prevent such risks.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: A “Skip to Content” link has been added at the top of the page to jump past menus and repetitive sections.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Keyboard users and screen reader users shouldn’t have to go through the same navigation every time. This makes browsing faster and easier.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Each page was given a clear and descriptive title in the code that reflects its content. You can see the page title in the tab bar.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People using screen readers rely on page titles to understand where they are, making navigation simpler.

wcag-a-2-4-3.title: 2.4.3 Focus Order (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The focus order must be logical and meaningful, ensuring that users navigating with a keyboard or assistive technology encounter elements in a predictable sequence that preserves meaning and operability.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: A logical focus order helps users who rely on keyboard navigation or screen readers to understand content structure and interact with elements efficiently. Without a proper focus order, navigation can be confusing or even make some features inaccessible.

wcag-a-2-4-3.implementation: Ensure elements receive focus in a meaningful sequence that aligns with the visual layout and reading order.
wcag-a-2-4-3.technique: Use semantic HTML, logical DOM order, and the `tabindex` attribute to control focus navigation.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Links now describe where they will take you, either through the link text itself or with the surrounding context.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People using screen readers need to know what a link does without guessing. Clear links make navigation easier for everyone.

wcag-a-2-5-1.title: 2.5.1 Pointer Gestures (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Complex pointer gestures (e.g., multi-finger swipes, pinching) must not be required for functionality. Users must be able to perform all actions with a simple pointer gesture (e.g., a single tap or click).

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with motor disabilities, those using assistive technologies, or those with limited dexterity may struggle with complex gestures. Providing simple alternatives ensures better usability and accessibility.

wcag-a-2-5-1.implementation: Ensure all actions can be performed using a single tap or click.
wcag-a-2-5-1.technique: Use event handlers that allow single-pointer interactions.

wcag-a-2-5-2.title: 2.5.2 Pointer Cancellation (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Interactive elements must allow users to cancel pointer inputs before they trigger an action, preventing accidental selections.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This prevents unintended actions caused by accidental touches or clicks, benefiting users with tremors or those navigating with assistive technologies.

wcag-a-2-5-2.implementation: Provide mechanisms to cancel or undo pointer actions.

wcag-a-2-5-3.title: 2.5.3 Label in Name (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The visible label of a UI element must match or be included in its programmatic name (accessible name) to support speech recognition users.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users who rely on speech recognition software need to be able to activate elements using their visible labels. A mismatch between visual and programmatic labels can create usability barriers.

wcag-a-2-5-3.implementation: Ensure that the accessible name includes the visible label.

changes.heading: What would change?
changes.text: Features that work by shaking or tilting a device would need an alternative way to be controlled with standard buttons.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: People who can’t perform physical movements (like shaking) still need a way to access the functionality.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The main language of the page is now clearly defined in the website’s code.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Screen readers need to know the language to pronounce words correctly. This helps people who rely on assistive technologies understand the content.

wcag-a-3-2-1.title: 3.2.1 On Focus (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: When an element receives focus, it must not trigger unexpected changes such as navigation, pop-ups, or automatic submissions. Users should maintain control over interactions.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Unexpected changes on focus can disorient users, particularly those with cognitive disabilities or screen reader users. Maintaining predictable behavior ensures a more accessible and usable interface.

wcag-a-3-2-1.implementation: Ensure focusable elements do not change context when focused.
wcag-a-3-2-1.technique: Avoid using `onfocus` event handlers to trigger unexpected actions.

wcag-a-3-2-2.title: 3.2.2 On Input (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Input fields must not automatically trigger significant changes (such as form submission or page navigation) without warning or confirmation.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users may make accidental changes or be confused if input fields trigger actions automatically. Providing control over submissions improves usability and accessibility.

wcag-a-3-2-2.implementation: Ensure user actions like pressing Enter or clicking submit buttons are required for major changes.
wcag-a-3-2-2.technique: Use explicit submission buttons instead of automatic input-triggered actions.

wcag-a-3-3-1.title: 3.3.1 Error Identification (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: When an error occurs in a form or an interactive element, it must be clearly identified, and users should be informed about how to correct it.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with disabilities, especially those with cognitive or visual impairments, may not recognize form errors without explicit feedback. Clear error identification improves usability and ensures users can successfully complete tasks.

wcag-a-3-3-1.implementation: Ensure error messages are presented clearly and in context with a description of what went wrong.
wcag-a-3-3-1.technique: Use ARIA live regions or inline error messages to notify users of errors.

wcag-a-3-3-2.title: 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Forms and interactive elements must include clear labels or instructions to guide users in providing the correct input.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with cognitive disabilities or screen reader users may struggle with ambiguous forms. Clear labels and instructions help users complete tasks accurately without frustration.

wcag-a-3-3-2.implementation: Use descriptive labels and provide inline instructions where necessary.
wcag-a-3-3-2.technique: Use `<label>` elements, placeholder text, and ARIA attributes to ensure proper guidance.

wcag-a-4-1-1.title: 4.1.1 Parsing (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: HTML, ARIA, and other code must be structured correctly so that browsers and assistive technologies can interpret them without errors. This includes correct nesting, unique IDs, and well-formed elements.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Assistive technologies rely on clean, error-free code to correctly interpret and present content. Parsing errors can lead to accessibility issues, making content unreadable or unusable.

wcag-a-4-1-1.implementation: Validate HTML and ensure all elements are properly nested and structured.
wcag-a-4-1-1.technique: Use the W3C Validator and linting tools to check for syntax errors.

wcag-a-4-1-2.title: 4.1.2 Name, Role, Value (A)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: All interactive elements must expose their name, role, and value programmatically so that assistive technologies can interpret and interact with them properly.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users who rely on screen readers or voice commands need clear, structured information about interface elements. If an element lacks a proper name, role, or value, it may be inaccessible or function unpredictably.

wcag-a-4-1-2.implementation: Ensure all interactive elements have ARIA attributes where needed.
wcag-a-4-1-2.technique: Use `aria-label`, `aria-labelledby`, and `role` attributes to define accessible names, roles, and values.

wcag-aa-1-2-4.title: 1.2.4 Captions (Live) (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Live audio content, such as broadcasts or streaming events, must include captions to provide real-time accessibility for users who are deaf or hard of hearing.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Without live captions, users with hearing impairments cannot follow spoken content in real time. Captions ensure inclusivity and equal access to live media.

wcag-aa-1-2-4.implementation: Use real-time captioning services or AI-generated live captions.
wcag-aa-1-2-4.technique: Integrate live transcription tools like CART or auto-captioning features in streaming platforms.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: An audio description track has been added to video. It explains visueal details in audio form to convey important information.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This ensures that blind or visually impaired users can understand what is happening in the video through spoken narration of key visual elements.

wcag-aa-1-3-4.title: 1.3.4 Orientation (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Content must be usable in both portrait and landscape orientations unless a specific display orientation is essential (e.g., for a game or a VR experience).

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Some users cannot easily rotate their devices due to physical disabilities, fixed screen orientations, or assistive technology. Allowing flexibility in orientation improves accessibility for all users.

wcag-aa-1-3-4.implementation: Ensure CSS does not force a specific orientation using media queries like `@media (orientation: landscape)` unless absolutely necessary.
wcag-aa-1-3-4.technique: Test sites on different devices and orientations to confirm usability without forced rotation.

wcag-aa-1-3-5.title: 1.3.5 Identify Input Purpose (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Input fields that collect user information (e.g., name, email, address) must have their purpose programmatically defined, allowing browsers and assistive technologies to recognize them.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This helps users who rely on autofill features, voice input, or assistive technology to navigate forms more easily. It improves efficiency and usability, particularly for people with cognitive or motor disabilities.

wcag-aa-1-3-5.implementation: Use HTML5 autocomplete attributes (e.g., `autocomplete='name'`, `autocomplete='email'`) to define input field purposes.
wcag-aa-1-3-5.technique: Implement ARIA attributes if necessary to further clarify input fields for assistive technologies.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The contrast between text and its background has been increased to meet a minimum ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text. This makes the text stand out more clearly against its background.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Good contrast ensures that text is easier to read, especially for people with low vision or color blindness. It also helps viewing content in bright sunlight or on low-quality screens. You can check the contrast of colors with contrast checker tools.

wcag-aa-1-4-4.title: 1.4.4 Resize Text (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must be able to resize text up to 200% without loss of content or functionality. The page layout should remain intact, and users should not have to scroll horizontally to read text.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Some users, especially those with low vision, rely on text resizing rather than screen magnifiers. Ensuring that text can be resized without breaking the layout improves readability and usability for a broader audience.

wcag-aa-1-4-4.implementation: Use relative units like `em`, `rem`, or percentages instead of fixed `px` values for font sizes. Ensure that layout containers adjust dynamically when text is resized.
wcag-aa-1-4-4.technique: Test zoom functionality by increasing text size to 200% in browser settings. Avoid text embedded in images, and ensure text wraps properly when resized.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The text that was displayed in the video thumbnail (as an image) is now also displayed as actual text.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Providing real text instead of images ensures better readability, scalability, and adaptability—allowing users to adjust text size, contrast, or use screen readers for better accessibility.

wcag-aa-1-4-10.title: 1.4.10 Reflow (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Content must reflow and remain usable without requiring horizontal scrolling when viewed at 320x256 pixels for vertical scrolling content and 256x320 pixels for horizontal scrolling content.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with low vision often need to zoom in, and horizontal scrolling makes content hard to read and navigate. Proper reflow ensures accessibility on small screens and zoomed-in views.

wcag-aa-1-4-10.implementation: Use responsive design techniques, such as flexible grids and media queries, to allow content to adapt fluidly to different screen sizes.
wcag-aa-1-4-10.technique: Avoid fixed widths in CSS and test with zoom settings at 400% in browsers.

wcag-aa-1-4-11.title: 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Essential visual elements like buttons, form fields, and icons must have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent colors.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with low vision or color deficiencies rely on sufficient contrast to identify interactive elements and distinguish content effectively.

wcag-aa-1-4-11.implementation: Ensure UI components like buttons and form fields meet contrast requirements. Use high-contrast color schemes where needed.
wcag-aa-1-4-11.technique: Use contrast checkers to verify compliance, and avoid low-contrast icons or placeholders.

wcag-aa-1-4-12.title: 1.4.12 Text Spacing (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must be able to adjust text spacing, including line height (1.5x), paragraph spacing (2x), letter spacing (0.12x), and word spacing (0.16x) without loss of functionality.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Some users, especially those with dyslexia or visual impairments, rely on adjusted text spacing for improved readability and comfort.

wcag-aa-1-4-12.implementation: Use CSS to allow users to control text spacing settings via stylesheets or browser extensions.
wcag-aa-1-4-12.technique: Test with increased spacing values and ensure content remains readable and functional.

wcag-aa-1-4-13.title: 1.4.13 Content on Hover or Focus (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Tooltips, pop-ups, and other hover/focus-triggered content must remain visible until dismissed and be dismissible without moving the pointer.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with motor impairments or screen magnifiers may struggle with disappearing hover elements, making content inaccessible.

wcag-aa-1-4-13.implementation: Ensure pop-ups persist when hovered and can be closed using both the keyboard and mouse.
wcag-aa-1-4-13.technique: Use ARIA roles (`aria-hidden`, `aria-live`), and test with keyboard navigation.

wcag-aa-2-4-5.title: 2.4.5 Multiple Ways (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must have more than one way to locate content, such as navigation menus, search functions, site maps, or breadcrumbs.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Providing multiple navigation options ensures that users with different abilities and preferences can find content efficiently.

wcag-aa-2-4-5.implementation: Include search, navigation menus, breadcrumbs, and sitemaps to support different user needs.
wcag-aa-2-4-5.technique: Ensure search functionality is available and provide descriptive labels for navigation elements.

wcag-aa-2-4-6.title: 2.4.6 Headings and Labels (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Headings and labels must clearly describe their associated content or function to ensure users understand their purpose.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Clear headings and labels improve navigation and usability, particularly for screen reader users who rely on them for page structure.

wcag-aa-2-4-6.implementation: Use semantic HTML (`<h1>` to `<h6>` for headings, `<label>` for form fields) and ensure labels are descriptive.
wcag-aa-2-4-6.technique: Provide unique and meaningful headings. Use `aria-labelledby` when necessary.

wcag-aa-2-4-7.title: 2.4.7 Focus Visible (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Keyboard users must be able to see which element is focused, ensuring clear visual indication of focus state.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users who navigate using a keyboard rely on a visible focus indicator to track their position on the page.

wcag-aa-2-4-7.implementation: Ensure all interactive elements (buttons, links, inputs) have a visible focus style using `:focus-visible` or `outline`.
wcag-aa-2-4-7.technique: Avoid removing focus indicators via `outline: none` unless replaced with an accessible alternative.

wcag-aa-3-1-2.title: 3.1.2 Language of Parts (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Sections of content in a different language must be correctly marked using the `lang` attribute.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Screen readers and other assistive technologies need language attributes to correctly pronounce and interpret multilingual content.

wcag-aa-3-1-2.implementation:
Use the `lang` attribute (`

Bonjour

`) to define language changes within content.
wcag-aa-3-1-2.technique: Ensure language is properly defined for each section. Test with screen readers.

wcag-aa-3-2-3.title: 3.2.3 Consistent Navigation (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Navigation elements must remain consistent across pages, preventing unexpected layout changes.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Predictable navigation reduces cognitive load and helps users with disabilities find information efficiently.

wcag-aa-3-2-3.implementation: Ensure menus, sidebars, and navigation links remain in the same relative order across pages.
wcag-aa-3-2-3.technique: Use templates for layout consistency. Avoid major navigation changes between pages.

wcag-aa-3-2-4.title: 3.2.4 Consistent Identification (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Elements with the same function (e.g., search fields, buttons) must be identified consistently across the site.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with cognitive or visual impairments rely on consistency to understand functions without relearning controls.

wcag-aa-3-2-4.implementation: Use consistent names, icons, and labels for interactive components throughout the site.
wcag-aa-3-2-4.technique: Maintain uniform wording for buttons (e.g., always 'Search' instead of 'Find' or 'Lookup').

wcag-aa-3-3-3.title: 3.3.3 Error Suggestion (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: When users make an error, suggestions must be provided to help them correct it.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with cognitive disabilities or language barriers benefit from helpful error messages that guide them toward correction.

wcag-aa-3-3-3.implementation: Include descriptive error messages with suggested fixes (e.g., 'Password must be at least 8 characters').
wcag-aa-3-3-3.technique: Use `aria-describedby` for input error hints. Provide autocomplete options when possible.

wcag-aa-4-1-3.title: 4.1.3 Status Messages (AA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Status messages (such as form validation, updates, or alerts) must be announced by assistive technologies without requiring focus.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users relying on screen readers need to be informed about changes on the page (e.g., form errors, loading states) without manually navigating to find them.

wcag-aa-4-1-3.implementation: Use ARIA live regions (`aria-live='polite'` or `aria-live='assertive'`) to announce dynamic status messages without shifting focus.
wcag-aa-4-1-3.technique: Apply `role='alert'` or `aria-live` attributes to elements that provide real-time updates.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The video now include sign language interpretation, typically displayed as an overlay or inset window. In this case, it is a placeholder of a person saying the word 'cooking' is ASL (American Sign Language).

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Deaf and hard-of-hearing users who rely on sign language can fully understand the content without needing to rely solely on captions or lip reading.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The video now includes an extended audio descriptions, giving more detail about the described visuals. If necessary, pausing the content for description could be a way to provide more detailed narration of key visual elements.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This ensures that important complex visuals are fully described, allowing blind or visually impaired users to access all critical information. For example for diagrams, gestures, etc.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: A full text alternative is provided for prerecorded media, describing both the dialogue and important visual information.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This ensures that users who cannot see or hear the content (e.g., deafblind users) can still access the information through text-based formats such as transcripts or descriptions.

wcag-aa-3-3-4.title: 3.3.4 Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data) (AA)

changes.heading: What would change?
changes.text: For legal, financial, or data transactions, users must be given opportunities to review, confirm, and correct their input before finalizing an action.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Mistakes in legal agreements, financial transactions, or important data entries can lead to serious consequences. Allowing users to check their input reduces the risk of errors and improves confidence in completing forms correctly.

wcag-aa-3-3-4.implementation: Provide confirmation steps before submission, allow users to review and edit their input, and offer an 'Undo' option where applicable.
wcag-aa-3-3-4.technique: Use modal dialogs for final confirmation. Implement 'Are you sure?' prompts for irreversible actions.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: The contrast between text and background has been increased to a higher ratio (7:1 for normal text, 4.5:1 for large text) to improve readability.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This helps people with low vision, color blindness, or in bright environments read text more easily, ensuring better accessibility and usability.

wcag-aaa-1-4-7.title: 1.4.7 Low or No Background Audio (AAA)

changes.heading: What would change?
changes.text: Audio content must have little to no background noise, or users should be able to turn off or reduce background sounds independently of foreground speech.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with hearing impairments, cognitive disabilities, or those in noisy environments struggle to understand speech if background audio is too loud or cannot be adjusted.

wcag-aaa-1-4-7.implementation: Provide separate audio tracks, volume controls, or an option to disable background sounds.
wcag-aaa-1-4-7.technique: Use captions, subtitles, or clear foreground audio with minimal distractions.

wcag-aaa-1-4-8.title: 1.4.8 Visual Presentation (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must be able to adjust text formatting, including line spacing, paragraph spacing, and contrast, without losing content or functionality.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with visual impairments, dyslexia, or cognitive disabilities may require specific text formatting to read comfortably.

wcag-aaa-1-4-8.implementation: Allow user-controlled text adjustments through browser settings or site customization options.
wcag-aaa-1-4-8.technique: Use relative units for spacing, support user stylesheets, and ensure text remains readable at different sizes.

wcag-aaa-1-4-9.title: 1.4.9 Images of Text (No Exception) (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: All text must be presented as actual text, not as part of an image, even if decorative or stylized.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Images of text cannot be resized, searched, or read aloud by assistive technologies, making content inaccessible to many users.

wcag-aaa-1-4-9.implementation: Use CSS styling for text effects instead of embedding text in images.
wcag-aaa-1-4-9.technique: Ensure all text content is in HTML and styled using web fonts and CSS instead of rasterized text images.

wcag-aaa-2-1-3.title: 2.1.3 Keyboard (No Exception) (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: All functionality must be accessible using only a keyboard, without requiring mouse or touch gestures, with no exceptions.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with motor disabilities or those using assistive technologies rely on keyboard-only navigation and cannot interact with content that requires a mouse.

wcag-aaa-2-1-3.implementation: Ensure all interactive elements can be fully operated with keyboard navigation.
wcag-aaa-2-1-3.technique: Use `tabindex`, `focus`, and `keydown` event listeners to enable full keyboard control.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: All timed content has been removed, or users are given unlimited time to complete actions without being forced to hurry.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This ensures that everyone, including people with cognitive or motor disabilities, can interact with the content at their own pace without stress or exclusion.

wcag-aaa-2-2-4.title: 2.2.4 Interruptions (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must be able to postpone or suppress interruptions unless they are essential, such as emergency alerts.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Unnecessary interruptions can distract users, especially those with cognitive or attention-related disabilities, making it difficult to complete tasks.

wcag-aaa-2-2-4.implementation: Provide user settings to control notifications and allow postponing of non-essential alerts.
wcag-aaa-2-2-4.technique: Use ARIA live regions appropriately and provide a way to disable or delay interruptions.

wcag-aaa-2-2-5.title: 2.2.5 Re-authenticating (AAA)

changes.heading: What would change?
changes.text: If a session expires, users must be able to re-authenticate and continue without losing their work.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with disabilities may take longer to complete tasks, and sudden session timeouts can cause frustration and data loss.

wcag-aaa-2-2-5.implementation: Implement automatic data saving and allow users to continue after re-authentication.
wcag-aaa-2-2-5.technique: Use session persistence techniques or provide warning messages before session expiration.

wcag-aaa-2-2-6.title: 2.2.6 Timeouts (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must be informed if an inactivity timeout is present and given an option to extend or adjust it.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Unexpected timeouts can disrupt users, especially those who require more time to process information or complete tasks.

wcag-aaa-2-2-6.implementation: Provide an alert before timeout expiration with an option to extend the session.
wcag-aaa-2-2-6.technique: Use modal dialogs or alerts that allow users to stay logged in or save progress.

wcag-aaa-2-3-2.title: 2.3.2 Three Flashes (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: No content may flash more than three times in one second to prevent seizures.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Flashing content can trigger seizures in people with photosensitive epilepsy, posing serious health risks.

wcag-aaa-2-3-2.implementation: Avoid rapid flashing effects or provide a mechanism to disable animations.
wcag-aaa-2-3-2.technique: Use video editing tools to detect and limit flash frequency.

wcag-aaa-2-3-3.title: 2.3.3 Animation from Interactions (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must be able to disable motion-based animations triggered by interactions, unless they are essential.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Excessive motion effects can cause dizziness or nausea, particularly in users with vestibular disorders.

wcag-aaa-2-3-3.implementation: Respect user preferences for reduced motion and provide an option to disable animations.

wcag-aaa-2-4-8.title: 2.4.8 Location (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must always be able to determine their location within a website, using elements like breadcrumbs, page titles, or navigation indicators.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users, particularly those with cognitive disabilities, can become disoriented when navigating a complex website. Clear location indicators help users understand where they are and how to return or proceed.

wcag-aaa-2-4-8.implementation: Provide breadcrumbs, clear headings, and persistent navigation to indicate the user's current location.
wcag-aaa-2-4-8.technique: Use ARIA landmarks, page titles, and structured navigation components such as breadcrumbs or a highlighted active menu item.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Links must be descriptive on their own, meaning the purpose of the link should be clear without relying on surrounding text.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This helps screen reader users and people quickly scanning a page to understand where a link leads without needing extra context, improving navigation and usability.

wcag-aaa-2-4-10.title: 2.4.10 Section Headings (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Content must be structured using clear and descriptive section headings to improve navigation and readability.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users, especially those using screen readers or with cognitive disabilities, rely on well-structured headings to understand and navigate content efficiently.

wcag-aaa-2-4-10.implementation: Use clear, meaningful headings to divide content logically, ensuring a structured reading flow.
wcag-aaa-2-4-10.technique: Apply semantic HTML headings (`<h1>` to `<h6>`), ensuring a logical order and avoiding skipping heading levels.

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Interactive elements like buttons and links must now have a minimum size of 44x44 pixels to make them easier to tap or click.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: This ensures that people with motor impairments, limited dexterity, or those using touchscreens can interact with elements more easily without accidental clicks.

wcag-aaa-2-5-6.title: 2.5.6 Concurrent Input Mechanisms (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users can switch between different input methods (e.g., keyboard, touchscreen, voice input) without restrictions.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Some users rely on multiple input methods for accessibility, and restricting them can create barriers to navigation and interaction.

targeting.heading: Targeting
targeting.target1: Web apps with custom input controls

wcag-aaa-2-5-6.implementation: Ensure that users can seamlessly use and switch between input methods without losing functionality.
wcag-aaa-2-5-6.technique: Design input fields and interactive elements to be fully operable using different input modalities.

wcag-aaa-3-1-3.title: 3.1.3 Unusual Words (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Difficult or uncommon words must be defined or explained to improve readability.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with cognitive disabilities, language learners, and screen readers benefit from clear explanations of unusual terminology.

wcag-aaa-3-1-3.implementation: Provide glossaries, tooltips, or inline definitions for specialized vocabulary.
wcag-aaa-3-1-3.technique: Use `<abbr title='Full Term'>Short</abbr>` or `<dfn>` elements for definitions.

wcag-aaa-3-1-4.title: 3.1.4 Abbreviations (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: All abbreviations must include an expansion or definition on first use.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Abbreviations can be confusing, especially for users with cognitive disabilities, screen readers, or those unfamiliar with the terms.

wcag-aaa-3-1-4.implementation: Provide an inline expansion or a glossary page with definitions.
wcag-aaa-3-1-4.technique: Use `<abbr title='World Wide Web'>WWW</abbr>` for HTML abbreviation tags.

wcag-aaa-3-1-5.title: 3.1.5 Reading Level (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Text should be written at a lower reading level or have an alternative summary at a simpler level.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Many users have cognitive disabilities, limited literacy skills, or are non-native speakers, making complex text hard to understand.

wcag-aaa-3-1-5.implementation: Use plain language and provide summaries in simple terms.
wcag-aaa-3-1-5.technique: Avoid complex sentence structures and jargon; use tools like Flesch-Kincaid readability tests.

wcag-aaa-3-1-6.title: 3.1.6 Pronunciation (AAA)

changes.heading: What would change?
changes.text: Words with ambiguous pronunciation should include phonetic guides or audio support.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Some words can be pronounced in multiple ways, causing confusion for screen readers and language learners.

wcag-aaa-3-1-6.implementation: Provide phonetic spellings, text-to-speech, or IPA transcriptions.
wcag-aaa-3-1-6.technique: Use `<ruby>` and `<rt>` HTML elements to display phonetic hints.

wcag-aaa-3-2-5.title: 3.2.5 Change on Request (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Unexpected changes (e.g., auto-submitting forms) must only occur after user confirmation.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with motor impairments, cognitive disabilities, or screen readers may not anticipate sudden changes in a page.

wcag-aaa-3-2-5.implementation: Require an explicit confirmation (e.g., 'Are you sure?') before major changes occur.
wcag-aaa-3-2-5.technique: Use modal dialogs or 'Submit' buttons instead of auto-submission.

wcag-aaa-3-3-5.title: 3.3.5 Help (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Websites and applications must provide help mechanisms, such as tooltips, documentation, live chat, or FAQs, to assist users in completing tasks.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Users with cognitive disabilities, limited digital literacy, or assistive technology reliance may struggle to complete tasks without contextual help.

wcag-aaa-3-3-5.implementation: Provide clear help options like inline hints, help buttons, or accessible support contact links.
wcag-aaa-3-3-5.technique: Use ARIA landmarks for help sections and ensure help content is easy to locate and navigate.

wcag-aaa-3-3-6.title: 3.3.6 Error Prevention (All) (AAA)

changes.heading: What has changed?
changes.text: Users must be able to review, confirm, and correct their inputs before finalizing any irreversible actions.

reason.heading: Why?
reason.text: Mistakes in forms, transactions, or data submissions can be frustrating and costly, especially for users with cognitive or motor impairments.

wcag-aaa-3-3-6.implementation: Include confirmation dialogs, undo options, and error-checking mechanisms before submission.
wcag-aaa-3-3-6.technique: Use clear summaries of entered information with an option to edit before submission.
